content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-263-06-A |Item_parent=Vascular nephropathy |Item_parent_short=Vascular nephropathy |Rank=A |Title=Savoir évoquer le diagnostic de sténose de l'artère rénale (How to diagnose renal artery stenosis) |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors=Jean-Jacques Boffa |Order=6}} There are 2 types of renal artery stenosis: atheromatous and fibrodysplastic. Table : The 2 types of renal artery stenosis {| class="wikitable" | |Atheromatous stenosis |Fibrodysplasia of the media". |- |Incidence |90% of cases |10% of cases |- |Terrain |male > 45 years, atheromatous |women between 25 and 40 |- |Cardiovascular risk factors |Multiple (hypertension, obesity, type 2 diabetes, smoking, etc.) |absent |- |'''Location''' '''of stenosis''' |proximal lesions (near the ostium) and often bilateral with post-stenotic dilatation |distal lesions with a a string of pearls, often bilateral |- |Risk of thrombosis |high |low |}

question.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of fibrodysplasia of the media in renal artery stenosis?
question.option_a: It is more common in males over 45 years old.
question.option_b: It is associated with multiple cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes.
question.option_c: It typically presents with distal lesions and a 'string of pearls' appearance.
question.option_d: It has a high risk of thrombosis.
